title: Cognitive ability, academic achievement and academic self-concept: Extending the internal/external frame of reference model
abstract: Background. Marsh's internal/external (I/E) frame of reference model depicts the relationship between achievement and self-concept in specific academic domains. Few efforts have been made to examine concurrent relationships among cognitive ability, achievement, and academic self-concept (ASC) within an I/E model framework. Aim. To simultaneously examine the influences of domain-specific cognitive ability and grades on domain self-concept in an extended I/E model, including the indirect effect of domain-specific cognitive ability on domain self-concept via grades. Sample. Tenth grade respondents (628 male, 452 female) to a national adolescent survey conducted in Taiwan. Method. Respondents completed surveys designed to measure maths and verbal aptitudes. Data on Maths and Chinese class grades and self-concepts were also collected. Results. Statistically significant and positive path coefficients were found between cognitive ability and self-concept in the same domain (direct effect) and between these two constructs via grades (indirect effect). The cross-domain effects of either ability or grades on ASC were negatively significant. Conclusions. Taiwanese 10th graders tend to evaluate their ASCs based on a mix of ability and achievement, with achievement as a mediator exceeding ability as a predictor. In addition, the cross-domain effects suggest that Taiwanese students are likely to view Maths and verbal abilities and achievements as distinctly different.

abstract.text: Background. Marsh's internal/external (I/E) frame of reference model depicts the relationship between achievement and self-concept in specific academic domains. Few efforts have been made to examine concurrent relationships among cognitive ability, achievement, and academic self-concept (ASC) within an I/E model framework. Aim. To simultaneously examine the influences of domain-specific cognitive ability and grades on domain self-concept in an extended I/E model, including the indirect effect of domain-specific cognitive ability on domain self-concept via grades. Sample. Tenth grade respondents (628 male, 452 female) to a national adolescent survey conducted in Taiwan. Method. Respondents completed surveys designed to measure maths and verbal aptitudes. Data on Maths and Chinese class grades and self-concepts were also collected. Results. Statistically significant and positive path coefficients were found between cognitive ability and self-concept in the same domain (direct effect) and between these two constructs via grades (indirect effect). The cross-domain effects of either ability or grades on ASC were negatively significant. Conclusions. Taiwanese 10th graders tend to evaluate their ASCs based on a mix of ability and achievement, with achievement as a mediator exceeding ability as a predictor. In addition, the cross-domain effects suggest that Taiwanese students are likely to view Maths and verbal abilities and achievements as distinctly different.

body_text.text: In multiple academic contexts, a positive sense of self is considered essential to motivation and academic achievement (Marsh, Craven, & McInerney, 2005; Skaalvik, 1997) . Engagement in classroom learning activities is also affected by achievement via the mediation of ability self-concept (Skaalvik, 1997) . Marsh (1986) established an internal/external (I/E) frame of reference model depicting the relationship between achievement and self-concept in specific academic domains. Marsh conceptualized internal and external references as comparative processes, through which academic achievement affects self-concept. According to the model, greater achievement in an academic domain supports the establishment of a strong self-concept in that domain, with students not only comparing their achievement with their peers (external reference) but also with their own achievements in other domains (internal reference). Regarding external references, students who perceive themselves as capable in relation to their peers in one domain should have a stronger self-concept in that domain. As for internal references, students who perform better in one domain than in others should have stronger self-concepts in that particular domain. Researchers in several countries have given broad support to the I/E model across different academic domains and some empirical evidence supporting specific model extensions (Goetz, Frenzel, Hall, & Pekrun, 2008; Marsh, Kong, & Hau, 2001; Möller & Savyon, 2003) .

Within the I/E model framework, achievement-measured as grades, teacher ratings, or standardized achievement test scores-has long been considered the primary predictor of academic self-concept (ASC). However, Brunner, Lüdtke, and Trautwein (2008) report that both domain-general and domain-specific cognitive abilities play important roles in predicting ASC within the I/E model. In educational settings, grades (as final outcomes) are influenced by multiple factors: individual characteristics such as cognitive ability and achievement motivation; environmental variables such as classroom climate; learning and cognitive processes; and teacher-centred factors such as instructional strategies. Among these, cognitive ability is generally perceived as the most important resource affecting academic achievement, in turn making a significant contribution to ASC.

In the 1960s, Brookover, Thomas, and Paterson (1964) and Davis (1966) suggested that due to its influence, cognitive ability needs to be controlled when predicting ASC based on academic achievement. This proposal was thought to purify predictions of achievement effects on ASC. Some researchers have emphasized the difference between cognitive abilities and school grades and their respective impacts on ASC (Hansford & Hattie, 1982; Marsh, 1987) . We believe that two goals can be achieved by treating ability and achievement as separate I/E model constructs: (1) purifying the effects of achievement on ASC, and (2) expanding the I/E model to include individual differences in characteristics such as intelligence, thus increasing the model's utility. It is also our belief that cognitive ability and achievement must be considered simultaneously when predicting ASC.

In terms of the connection between cognitive ability and academic achievement, there is broad agreement regarding their positive relationship. Cognitive ability is conceptualized as innate capacity (Anastasi & Urbina, 1997; Deary, Strand, Smith, & Fernandes, 2007) , while achievement represents outcome performance obtained through daily learning, built on a foundation of cognitive ability. The causal relationship between cognitive ability and achievement is supported by Watkins, Lei, and Canivez (2007) , who present evidence from a longitudinal study indicating that intelligence influences future achievement. Despite acknowledged factors, such as motivation, social economic status, and parental involvement, some researchers still describe cognitive ability as the primary predictor of academic success (Deary et al., 2007; Gagné & St Père, 2002; Rohde & Thompson, 2007; Spinath, Spinath, Harlaar, & Plomin, 2006) .

Relationships among cognitive ability, achievement, and ASC have been described by Marsh (1990a) . Using results from a longitudinal study, he showed that cognitive ability impacts school grades, and that the two factors affect ASC formation. However, to our knowledge no efforts have been made to determine how cognitive ability directly and/or indirectly impacts ASC within the I/E model framework.

Note that frames of reference differ according to culture and educational setting. In Taiwan, cognitive ability test scores are sometimes used as references in self-evaluations of domain ability, especially by high school students who are choosing among academic tracks that require either strong maths or verbal skills. Accordingly, a primary motivation for this study is examining the influence of cognitive ability on school grades, and the influences of both constructs on ASC within an extended I/E model, using 10th-grade Taiwanese students as our sample. Shavelson, Hubner, and Stanton's (1976) multi-dimensional and hierarchical model has global self-concept (divided into academic and non-academic categories) at its apex. Examples of non-ASC include self-perceptions of moral characteristics, social popularity, and other personal factors. ASC refers to how people conceptualize their own abilities in a particular academic domain. Global ASC can be divided into specific domains (e.g., maths, language arts, science) that are measurable via responses to survey items such as 'Am I doing well in maths class'? (Bong & Skaalvik, 2003) .

ASC formation and its predictive utility have been extensively examined over the past few decades. Regarding external frames of reference, Marsh and Parker (1984) have noted that students form their ASCs based on their relative perceptions of their own academic abilities compared to those of other students. Empirical evidence has been presented indicating strong correlations between maths and verbal achievement and between achievement and self-concept within individual domains (Shavelson et al., 1976; Skaalvik & Rankin, 1995; Marsh & Shavelson, 1985) . In contrast, a very weak correlation has been observed between maths and verbal self-concepts (Marsh, 1986; Marsh & Craven, 1997) . Marsh (1986) developed his I/E frame of reference model to explain the relatively stronger correlation between maths and verbal achievement.
body_text.section: The I/E frame of reference model

body_text.text: According to the I/E model, (1) a strong correlation exists between maths and verbal achievement, (2) maths and verbal self-concept are nearly un-correlated or substantially less correlated than the typically large correlation between maths and verbal achievement, (3) verbal achievement has a strong and positive effect on verbal selfconcept but a weak and negative effect on maths self-concept, and (4) maths achievement has a strong and positive effect on maths self-concept but a weak and negative effect on verbal self-concept (Marsh, 1986; Marsh, Byrne, & Shavelson, 1988) . External frame of reference refers to a social comparison process in which students compare their maths or verbal abilities with the perceived abilities of others. The model suggests that students who perceive themselves as capable compared to other students in a specific domain tend to have high self-concepts in that domain. It also suggests that students compare their self-perceived performance in one domain with their own performances in other domains-an internal frame of reference. For example, students who are better in maths than in verbal subjects tend to use relative perceptions of their abilities to form better self-concepts in maths, even though they may not be especially successful in maths classes. Internal and external references work jointly to establish an individual's self-concept in a particular domain.
body_text.section: The I/E frame of reference model

body_text.text: I/E research has expanded in multiple directions since the model was first introduced-for instance, Marsh et al.'s (1988) report of little difference between male and female students after adding a gender variable. Findings on gifted/honour and special educational programmes during the past two decades have supported the use of Marsh's model to explain self-concept formation among academically able and disabled students (Möler, Streblow, & Pohlmann, 2009; Plucker & Stocking, 2001; Williams & Montgomery, 1995) . In addition, multi-group structural equation models have been used to demonstrate the cross-cultural generalizability of the I/E frame of reference across 26 countries (Marsh & Hau, 2004) . Möller and Savyon (2003) extended the model to include non-academic domains and found that academic achievement negatively influences such non-ASCs as honesty. Goetz et al. (2008) used an extended I/E model to argue that domain self-concept is a mediator of the achievement effect on academic enjoyment in specific domains. Marsh et al. (2001) applied the I/E model to examine relationships among maths, English, and Chinese achievement and their respective self-concepts, and Möller, Streblow, Pohlmann, and Köller (2006) applied it to verbal domains such as German and English, as well as to maths-related domains such as Physics. Möller, Pohlmann, Köller, and Marsh (2009) analysed 69 data sets from past I/E studies and found considerable support for the model (e.g., meta-analytic path coefficients based on all studies ranged from .49 to .61 for external frame of reference and −.21 to −.27 for internal frame of reference). I/E model generalizability has been examined longitudinally and shown to be stable over time (Marsh et al., 2001 ).

cite_spans.text: and Möller, Streblow, Pohlmann, and Köller (2006)

body_text.section: The I/E frame of reference model

body_text.text: For decades, researchers have associated cognitive ability with academic achievement, with several reporting moderate-to-strong correlations (Bachman, 1970; Marsh & Craven, 1997) . For example, Gustafsson and Balke (1993) reported a correlation of .50 between measures of general cognitive ability and educational achievement, and Mackintosh (1998) reported correlations of .40 to .70 between intelligence quotient (IQ) scores and school grades. Despite Rohde and Thompson's (2007) finding that between 51% and 75% of variance in academic achievement is not accounted for by measures of cognitive ability alone, many researchers still argue that it is the main predictor of academic achievement (Deary et al., 2007; Garné & St Père, 2008; Rohde & Thompson, 2007; Spinath et al., 2006) . Specific examples include Watkins et al.'s (2007) conclusion from a longitudinal study that intelligence influences future achievement, and Laidra, Pullmann, and Allik's (2007) assertion that cognitive ability is the most important factor determining academic achievement from elementary through high school. Bachman (1970) reported a positive correlation between cognitive ability and ASC (r = .41), but Spinath et al. (2006) have more recently described a weak (.18-.25) and positive association between cognitive ability and self-perceptions of ability. Results from Marsh's (1990a) longitudinal study indicate that cognitive ability impacts school grades and that both factors can be used to predict ASC. Brunner et al. (2008) recently created an alternative I/E model focusing on relationships between domain-general cognitive ability and domain-general self-concept, as well as between domain-specific cognitive ability and domain-specific self-concept. Although not explicitly mentioned, Brunner et al.'s results suggest that domain-specific cognitive abilities impact ASC in the same domain to a greater degree than domain-general cognitive abilities.
body_text.section: Relationship of cognitive ability to achievement and ASC

body_text.text: Researchers have shown that ability test scores and achievement measures such as grades are predictors of ASC, but most investigators have treated these factors independently within the I/E model framework. We recognize that ability and achievement are associated in the same manner that many researchers conceptualize cognitive abilities as having an innate power to predict individual academic performance (Deary et al., 2007; Garné & St Père, 2008; Rohde & Thompson, 2007; Snow, 1998; Spinath et al., 2006) . Marsh (1990a) and Marsh and Craven (1997) have also reported that cognitive ability impacts both school grades and ASC and that ASC can be predicted by cognitive ability and school grades. We therefore believe that establishing a link between cognitive ability and school grades and investigating them simultaneously will provide a more complete picture of the influences of cognitive ability and achievement on ASC within an I/E model frame.

To predict ASC, we propose an extension of the I/E model that includes cognitive ability and achievement, with achievement serving as a mediator between ability and ASC. Specifically, our extended I/E model posits (1) a direct effect of domain-specific cognitive ability and school grades on ASC, and (2) an indirect effect of domain-specific cognitive ability on ASC via school grades. As is the case with the standard I/E model, our extended model assumes that domain-specific cognitive ability and school grades exert impacts on self-concept in the same domain as well as in other domains.

A sample consisting of Taiwanese high school students is suitable for this study, since cognitive ability test scores are important references for student self-evaluations of competence in different domains; students use this information to determine their academic tracks (also referred to as groups). Group one students are more strongly oriented toward liberal arts/social studies, group two students toward maths and nonbiological science, and group three students toward maths and all sciences. In the 10th grade, Taiwanese students must select a specific academic track leading to the national college entrance examination, which determines college placement and majors that can lead to optimum professional futures. Tenth graders may evaluate their academic abilities or achievement from various sources in addition to their grades. Many high schools provide their students with cognitive ability test scores to use as references when choosing an academic track.

Several other studies have looked at the applicability of the I/E model in Chinesespeaking countries. In their study of Hong Kong high school students, Marsh et al. (2001) used high-stakes standardized exams to find support for the I/E model; they analysed achievement and self-concepts in maths, English, and Chinese classes. Marsh and Hau (2004) also found support for the I/E model using data from the Program of International Student Assessment database compiled by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). Chiu (2008) investigated the I/E model using data of Taiwanese students from the 2003 Trends in International Maths and Science Study (TIMSS) and compared them with data from 27 other countries that participated in the survey. According to her results, the cross-domain effect varied across different countries. Some limitations for the above research studies need to be mentioned. In Marsh and Hau (2004) and Chiu's (2008) studies, achievement measures were based on a compromise framework agreed upon by all participating countries, and therefore may not fully represent the achievement or self-concept realities of individual countries. Also, Chiu focused on maths and science only; no consistent results were found across countries, due to what she calls the supplementary relation between maths and science. Research studies have shown that the internal comparison is more obvious when the two domains in the I/E model are distinct such as maths and verbal abilities . To avoid these shortcomings aforementioned, our proposed I/E model extension addresses maths and Chinese language studies. In addition, we used school grades instead of international achievement test scores in our analysis.
Our specific research questions are

(1) Is the I/E model applicable to a Taiwanese student sample when grades are used as predictors? Is it applicable to a Taiwanese student sample, when domain-specific cognitive abilities are used as predictors? (2) Can school grades be treated as mediators of the cognitive ability effect on ASC within the I/E model? (3) Is cognitive ability or achievement a better predictor of ASC? (4) In the proposed I/E model, what role does cognitive ability play in predicting ASC across domains?

We used four models to address these questions: Model 1 (Figure 1 ), the original I/E model, aimed at testing model applicability to a Taiwanese student sample when grades are used as predictors; Model 2 ( Figure 2 ), a domain-specific cognitive ability I/E model, in which domain-specific cognitive abilities are used as predictors (Question 1); Model 3 ( Figure 3) , extended from the original academic achievement-based I/E model, in which the effect of cognitive ability on ASC is added, and school grades are treated as mediators (Question 2); and Model 4 ( Figure 4 ), extended from Model 3 by the addition of paths from domain-specific cognitive abilities to self-concept in non-corresponding domains. Results from Model 3 help determine whether cognitive ability or achievement is a better predictor of ASC. Comparisons of models 1 and 3, 1 and 4, and 2 and 4 provide additional support for determining the relative weights of cognitive ability and achievement in terms of self-concept (Question 3). The Model 3 and 4 comparison was used to analyse the role of cognitive ability in predicting ASC across domains within the proposed I/E model (Question 4).

Participants and procedure Participants were drawn from the list of respondents to a 2007 national adolescent survey funded by the Republic of China (ROC) National Academy for Educational Research. Survey questions were designed to collect demographic, school performance, and physical and mental development data. Regional clusters were classified according to official Taiwan territorial divisions (north-west, mid-west, south-west, and east/islands). Numbers and percentages of participating schools and students in each region were determined according to 2007 educational statistics published by the ROC Ministry of Education (2007) . Schools were randomly selected in each region, and one class was randomly selected from each school. The final sample consisted of 1,080 10th-grade students (628 male, 452 female) who completed questionnaires assessing their aptitudes and ASCs. Participation was voluntary and anonymous, and students were assured that their teachers would not be given any information about their answers.

We used three indicators with the extended I/E model, with cognitive ability and academic achievement serving as predictors and ASC as the outcome variable. ASC and cognitive ability data were, respectively, obtained using Marsh's (1990b) Academic Self-Description Questionnaire II (ASDQ II) and Lu and Ou's (2003) Multiple Dimension Aptitude Test Battery (MDATB). Maths and Chinese grades (ranging from 1 to 100 according to the system used in Taiwan) were provided by school administrators.

The ASDQ II, which Marsh (1990b) developed to assess students' self-perceptions about achievement, consists of sub-scales corresponding to specific school domains. Each subscale includes six items that are parallel across all domains. Items were written to direct respondent attention to past accomplishments, including some forms of cognitive evaluations and affective reactions. We constructed Chinese versions for maths and Chinese language studies, with each item being identical except for the words 'maths' or 'Chinese'. Participants completed the scales based on a mix of how their abilities compare to those of other students and how their domain-specific abilities match up with their abilities in other domains. Example items are 'Compared to others my age, I am good at maths/Chinese'; 'I get good marks in maths/Chinese'; and 'Work in maths/Chinese class is easy for me'. Answers were given along a five-point scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). Based on Hair, Black, Babin, Anderson, and Tatham's (2006) suggestion that four items per factor is preferable for obtaining adequate identification and minimum coverage of construct, we included four items for each domain. Coefficient alpha reliability estimates for the data were .95 for maths and .92 for Chinese-both considered high. Lu and Ou (2003) designed the MDATB to measure the cognitive abilities of students to learn or succeed in different areas and to provide a baseline for educational/career guidance and counselling for high school students. The battery consists of several subtests, with reading comprehension and verbal reasoning sub-tests serving as verbal ability indicators. Numerical reasoning and maths application sub-tests were combined to serve as a single maths-ability indicator. Lu and Ou have reported satisfactory reliability and validity statistics for this instrument. Coefficient alpha reliability estimates for our data were .91 for maths ability and .90 for verbal ability.

Maths and Chinese grades (ranging from 1 to 100) were converted to T scores based on class norms-in other words, grades relative to each class were used to represent individual student domain performance. Although comparable students may have different T scores because of school/assessment difference, students' perceptions of ASC more strongly rely on their grades (class/school relative position) than their standardized achievement (Marsh & Craven, 2006; . This is because the social comparison/external comparison is assumed to occur within a class/school.

Model adequacy was evaluated using LISREL 8.72 (Jöreskog & Sörbom, 1993) . As recommended by McDonald and Ho (2002) , goodness-of-fit was assessed using chisquare analyses and three fit indexes: root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA), comparative fit index (CFI), and standardized root mean square residual (SRMR).

Descriptive statistics and inter-correlations among ASDQ II items for maths and Chinese, maths and verbal ability scores, and maths and Chinese grades are presented in Table 1 . As shown, average ASC question ratings ranged from 2.49 to 2.85. Data for latent ability, achievement, and ASC in confirmatory factor analyses (CFA; see Table 2 ) indicate several statistically significant and positive relationships among ASC, ability, and achievement within the same domain. 1 The data also indicate positive associations between maths ability and verbal ability 2 and between maths achievement and Chinese achievement. Statistically significant and negative correlations were found between maths self-concept and Chinese self-concept as well as between achievement in one domain and ASC in another. Ability in one domain was not associated with achievement and ASC in another, with the exception of maths ability and Chinese self-concept. Statistically significant standardized path coefficients among the latent constructs in Model 1 are presented in Figure 1 . As shown in Table 3 , the model fit indexes for Model 1 were satisfactory (RMSEA = 0.072, CFI = 0.98, SRMR = 0.033). The results indicate (1) a strong and positive effect of Chinese achievement on Chinese self-concept but a weak and negative effect on maths self-concept; (2) a strong and positive effect of maths achievement on maths self-concept but a weak and negative effect on Chinese selfconcept; and (3) a .28 correlation between maths achievement and Chinese achievement (p < .01), but no correlation between maths self-concept and Chinese self-concept. These results confirm the explanatory power of the I/E frame of reference when school grades were used as predictors.

1 The relation between academic ability and academic achievement was high; however, it does not indicate they are the same constructs. Discriminant validity of achievement and ability was examined by looking at the confidence interval (±two standard errors) around the correlation between the two factors. The confidence interval around the correlation including 1.0 indicates that the two constructs are not discriminant (Anderson & Gerbing, 1988) . In the present study, the 95% confidence interval of correlation between the maths ability and maths achievement constructs is between 0.16 and 0.28, and the one between the verbal ability and Chinese achievement ranges from 0.10 to 0.22. Therefore, the correlation between ability and achievement within the same domain are significantly less than 1.0, providing evidence for discriminant validity.

2 Since the correlation between maths ability and verbal ability is .62, some might question the accuracy of path coefficient estimates and theory test due to collinearity problems. According to Grewal, Cote, and Baumgartner (2004) , if measurement reliability is high (Ͼ.80) and sample size is large, the type II error due to collinearity could be negligible. Domain-specific cognitive abilities served as Model 2 predictors. Model 2 was also found to have an adequate fit (RMSEA = 0.064, CFI = 0.99, SRMR = 0.029) ( Table 2 ). Our Model 2 results ( Figure 2 ) indicate a positive impact of verbal ability on Chinese selfconcept but a negative impact on maths self-concept. In contrast, maths ability exerted a strong and positive influence on maths self-concept but a weak and negative influence on Chinese self-concept. The effect of verbal ability on Chinese self-concept was not as strong as the effect of maths ability on maths self-concept. The results also show that the association between maths self-concept and Chinese self-concept was substantially less than the correlation between maths ability and verbal ability.

After adding maths and verbal abilities as antecedents to the I/E model (with maths and Chinese achievement serving as predictors), Model 3 still expressed the explanatory power of the I/E frame of reference. The model fit indexes shown in Table 3 indicate an adequate fit for Model 3 (RMSEA = 0.071, CFI = 0.98, SRMR = 0.055). As shown in Figure 3 , maths ability exerted a significant and direct impact on maths self-concept (␤ = 0.23) and a significant but indirect impact on maths self-concept via maths achievement (␤ = 0.16). Verbal ability had a direct but weak effect (␤ = 0.06) on Chinese self-concept and an indirect effect on Chinese self-concept via Chinese achievement (␤ = 0.10). The impact of achievement in one domain on self-concept in another was approximately the same as in Model 1.

As shown in Table 3 , selected fit index values of Model 4 were RMSEA = 0.069, CFI = 0.98, and SRMR = 0.045, indicating an adequate model fit to the data. Maths ability was found to have a positive impact on both maths achievement and maths selfconcept and a negative impact on Chinese self-concept (Figure 4) . Verbal ability had a positive effect on both Chinese achievement and Chinese self-concept and a negative effect on maths self-concept. Furthermore, maths achievement had a strong and positive effect on maths self-concept but a weak and negative effect on Chinese self-concept, and Chinese achievement had a strong and positive effect on Chinese self-concept but a weak and negative effect on maths self-concept. A positive and statistically significant effect was found for maths ability on maths self-concept via maths achievement. The results also indicate that verbal ability exerted a statistically significant impact on Chinese self-concept, as mediated by Chinese achievement.

The results of Models 1 and 2 address whether the typical I/E model applies to a Taiwanese student sample (Question 1). Model 3 answers whether school grades are mediators of the cognitive ability effects on ASCs within the I/E model (Question 2). To answer whether cognitive ability or achievement is a better predictor of ASC (Question 3), the following observations are particularly valuable. First, in Model 3, the effect of maths achievement was stronger than the effect of maths ability on maths self-concept (␤ = 0.60 vs. ␤ = 0.23); the same was true for the effects of Chinese achievement and verbal ability on Chinese self-concept (␤ = 0.50 vs. ␤ = 0.06). In other words, after controlling for the other constructs, achievement had a stronger association than ability with self-concept in the same domain. Second, according to a comparison of Models 1 and 3, the achievement-to-self concept paths in Model 1 were only slightly affected by the addition of maths and verbal ability constructs (Model 3)-specifically, decreased by 8% (from ␤ = 0.65 to ␤ = 0.60) for maths and 2% (from ␤ = 0.51 to ␤ = 0.50) for Chinese. After mixing Models 1 and 2 to produce Model 4, the path coefficients between achievement and self-concept in the same domain also decreased by small amounts: 11% (0.65-0.58) for maths and 4% (0.51-0.49) for Chinese. Third, results from a comparison of Models 2 and Model 4 clearly show reductions in path coefficients between ability and self-concept in the same domain: 38% (0.55-0.34) for maths and 64% (0.28-0.10) for Chinese (taking achievement and self-concept paths into account).

Model 3 and 4 results were compared in order to address the fourth research question (i.e., what role do cognitive abilities play in cross-domain effects?). We found that due to the high correlation (r = .62) between maths ability and verbal ability identified in Model 4, the magnitude of the direct effect of maths ability on maths self-concept increased (from 0.23 to 0.34) due to the suppression effect caused by verbal ability. The influence of verbal ability on Chinese self-concept increased from 0.06 to 0.10 after accounting for the negative effect of verbal ability on maths self-concept.

The Model 1 results support the use of the original I/E model (based on achievement) in a Taiwanese context. The positive path coefficient leading from cognitive ability to self-concept (Model 2) also suggests that students engage in social comparison processes within an external frame of reference (most likely their fellow students). The negative impact of a student's cognitive ability in one domain on self-concept in another implies that students who succeed in maths are likely to have lower Chinese self-concepts and vice versa. In general, the Model 1 and 2 results-as well as those reported by Marsh et al. (2001) and Marsh and Hau (2004) for cross-cultural studies using the I/E model-suggest that non-Western students form their ASCs based on a mix of internal and external frames of reference.
body_text.section: The original and extended I/E model

body_text.text: Our intent for Model 3 was to determine whether the effects of cognitive ability on ASC were mediated by school grades (Question 2). The findings suggest that Taiwanese students who are strong in maths are more likely to have higher maths self-concepts, which may be explained (at least in part) by the fact that students who are competent in maths tend to receive higher grades in maths. The results also indicate that verbal ability directly influenced Chinese self-concept and partly influenced Chinese self-concept via Chinese grades. We therefore conclude that ability exerts significant direct and indirect impacts on self-concept in the same domain, with the indirect impact mediated by achievement. In other words, ASC formation cannot be interpreted solely by achievement or ability.
body_text.section: The original and extended I/E model

body_text.text: Regarding which of the two predictors (cognitive abilities or achievement) is better predictor of ASC in the same domain (Question 3), we found achievement has more explanatory power than ability. Although both ability and achievement are sources of information for domain self-concept evaluation or development, in practice, information on achievement relative to specific classes is usually provided to students (mostly from teachers) more frequently than information on cognitive abilities as measured by aptitude tests and, therefore, has greater impact on ASC formation . Our results support arguments that (1) sources of information on internal and external comparisons are crucial to ASC, and (2) the impacts of internal and external comparisons on self-concept in a specific domain depend on the extent and frequency of information that students have access to (Skaalvik & Skaalvik, 2002) . There exist another possible explanation to the distinct explanatory powers of ability and achievement. Steven and Stigler (1992) describe Chinese students as perceiving different weights on ability and achievement: ability is not the major determinant of an individual's success-effort and final achievement play more important roles. Accordingly, how well students perform academically may exert a stronger influence than ability on their ASCs.
body_text.section: The original and extended I/E model

body_text.text: In spite of aforementioned explanations, one should pay attention to the possible limitation of ASDQ II. The majority of the questions in ASDQ II are concerning school performance/achievement; a most obvious example is 'I get good marks in maths/Chinese'. This could also partially explain why ASC is more associated with school grades than with ability. A different set of questions, not dominantly asking about school performance, are suggested in the future, when both cognitive ability and achievement are predictors of ASC.
body_text.section: The original and extended I/E model

body_text.text: With regard to what role cognitive abilities play in cross-domain effects (Question 4), our data showed that verbal ability acted as a suppressor variable in the path leading from maths ability to maths self-concept, removing the irrelevant variance influencing the association between maths ability and maths self-concept. We found similar patterns for the enhanced influence of verbal ability on Chinese self-concept. In general, crossdomain effects in the I/E model exist for both ability and achievement. When Models 1 and 2 were combined, we found that the cross-domain effects from ability to ASC were much smaller than those from achievement to ASC (Figure 4) , perhaps due to the higher correlation between maths ability and verbal ability compared to that between maths achievement and Chinese achievement. Because of this strong correlation, adding the cross-domain effect removes the confounding effects and increases the direct effects of ability on self-concept in the same domain.
body_text.section: The original and extended I/E model

body_text.text: This finding implies that when an individual student evaluates self-concept in one domain, whether the cognitive ability information in another domain is provided leads to a different evaluation process. If cognitive ability information in Chinese is accessible and internal comparison is involved, students who are relatively high (or low) in maths in comparison with their peers will perceive themselves good (or inferior) in maths with inversed influence of Chinese ability. This perception of maths ability relies more on social comparison when internal comparison is involved than when no cognitive ability information is provided and no internal comparison is processed. That is, social comparison is emphasized when students know ability of the other domain. The same interpretation also applies to the evaluation of Chinese self-concept. Since this is just a speculated interpretation of the suppressor relationships, some questions remain open. Whether the suppression effect will be observed in other contexts needs further investigations.
body_text.section: The original and extended I/E model

body_text.text: In Model 4, the total effect of maths ability on maths self-concept was 0.49 and of verbal ability on Chinese self-concept was 0.20. The direct effect of verbal ability on Chinese self-concept was particularly low compared to that of maths ability on maths self-concept. The content emphasis for MDATB maths ability items is similar to those in the national high school maths curriculum. However, the Chinese curriculum focuses on classical Chinese literature, which is slightly different than the modern Chinese language usage emphasized in MDATB. This difference may explain, at least in part, the lower association between verbal ability and Chinese self-concept that we observed. Although not discussed, Möller et al.'s meta-analysis results (2009) showed that maths achievement is associated with maths self-concept in a stronger magnitude than is verbal achievement with verbal self-concept. We believe some characteristics of maths and verbal abilities may determine their relationship with self-concept in the same domain. For example, maths is somewhat harder than verbal/language studies and requires problem solving abilities not simply obtained through practice. Therefore, it is possible that the variance of maths performance is larger than verbal, leading to higher correlation between maths ability/achievement and maths self-concept.
body_text.section: The original and extended I/E model

body_text.text: What does the cross-domain effect mean in the present study and past I/E model studies? Skaalvik and Rankin (1992) note that within the original I/E model, the negative cross-domain effects occur when students subjectively view the two domains as being different. According to , students who perceive negative correlations between maths and verbal abilities tend to emphasize internal comparisons when forming domain self-concepts. Our results from the cross-domain effect in Models 1 to 4 indicate that Taiwanese students believe that maths and verbal ability/achievement have little (if any) positive association and therefore view ability/achievement in one as less ability/achievement in the other.

Recently, the psychological processes of cross-domain effects have been studied using field studies and experimental designs. Several researchers (Möller & Köller, 2001; Möller & Husemann, 2006; manipulated various feedbacks to induce dimensional or internal comparisons. The results showed that dimensional comparisons have contrasting or inverse effects on domain-specific self-concept as it is postulated by Marsh (1986) . Specifically, the gains in the domain-specific self-concepts resulting from downward dimensional comparisons are larger in absolute terms than the losses resulting from upward dimensional comparisons . The possible psychological mechanics of this finding could be that students unconsciously avoid looking inferior academically .

Incorporating ability and grades in the same I/E model suggests that development of domain self-concept not only involves a psychological process of external comparison and internal comparison but also the evaluation of relative importance of ability and grades. For an individual who has average ability, but achieve above-average grades, his/her domain self-concept is higher in comparison with students who have aboveaverage abilities but average grades. This was proved in a separate study using the same data as this study. The process behind these may involve factors determining the selection or weighting of the reference. Factors determining which reference to use may depend on the availability of the information, which is also applied to the comparison theories in other areas such as social psychology or organizational psychology (Goodman, 1974; Grienberger, Rutte, & Van Knippenberg, 1997) . Students obtain information about their grades from teachers' feedback or class performance more frequently than their ability test scores Skaalvik & Skaalvik, 2002) . Another speculation is that the relative importance of ability and achievement in students' perception is not equal. Although we observed different strength of crossdomain effects leading from ability and from achievement, our study does not provide evidence that these internal comparison processes are different. Little difference in psychological process, if any, could be due to the relative weighting of ability and achievement.
body_text.section: Cognitive ability and grades in the I/E model

body_text.text: Limitation and future study Since our extended model was only examined based on correlations among constructs, the comparison processes behind the effects within the extended I/E model can only be inferred (Marsh et al., 2001; . Experimental designs with sophisticated manipulation will allow deeper investigation of psychological mechanics of the information selection and comparison process. A qualitative approach can also provide insights of possible factors influencing external and internal comparison processes. For example, it is likely that students who have extremely high grades attempt to compare themselves with high performing students. However, when they receive low grades, they engage in social comparison adopting low-performing students as criterion. Based on the predictive relationship extended from the I/E model, our findings provide possible directions of future research, for example, whether students' efforts involve in the development of ASC, and how students predict their success in one domain and in turn influence their selection of courses (or groups in Taiwan). In a society such as Taiwan, where maths achievement is more emphasized than verbal achievement, will the self-enhancement involved in self-evaluation impact more on maths ability/achievement? Moreover, is it necessary to divide self-concept in a domain into ability and achievement dimensions? All these questions remain open and require further research.
body_text.section: Cognitive ability and grades in the I/E model

body_text.text: Several other factors must also be considered in the future study. For example, the juxtaposition of ability and achievement within the I/E model needs to be examined using samples from different grade levels, in different types of schools (e.g., college track vs. non-college track high schools), or in different cultures. There is also a need to investigate the causal relationships among cognitive ability, achievement, and ASCs within the I/E model using multi-wave path analysis techniques such as those described by Marsh (1990a) .
body_text.section: Cognitive ability and grades in the I/E model

body_text.text: In summary, this study's primary contribution addresses the influences of cognitive ability and achievement on ASC within the I/E model, especially in aspects that are contextually determined. Our results suggest that both cognitive ability and grades impact ASCs among Taiwanese 10th graders in three ways. First, ability influences self-concept in the same domain both directly and indirectly, the latter via school grades. Second, achievement seems to play a more salient role than ability in predicting self-concept in the same domain, even though cognitive ability test scores are considered valuable information for academic track selection. Third, increases in the effect of ability on self-concept in a domain occur once the cross-domain comparison is available. Students with lower verbal abilities tend to believe that their maths skills are good. A similar interpretation can also be applied to Chinese self-concept formation; although, the negative effect of maths ability on Chinese self-concept is weak.

Teachers must consider cognitive ability as an antecedent of achievement and ASC. However, they must also recognize that students with only fair ability but high achievement in a domain tend to perceive themselves as better in that domain, whereas students with fair ability but low achievement tend to have lower self-concept in the same domain. This may be especially true in the Taiwanese context. To enhance students' domain self-concepts, it is better to emphasize their academic achievements than their ability. Efforts toward enhancement should be aimed at interventions such as raising motivations and encouraging the use of learning strategies. More importantly, teachers should place less emphasis on social comparisons such as normative grade references and instead introduce self-improvement or task-absolute references when providing feedback on academic performance (e.g., see Martin, 2006; Martin & Liem, 2010) . Positive selftalk and positive thinking should also be taught and encouraged (Burnett, 1999; Barrett, Webster, & Wallis, 1999) .

Usually, students with strong maths abilities have strong verbal abilities. However, teachers should not assume equal ASCs across domains. For example, a student who is bright in maths may have below average maths self-concept when his/her verbal ability is relatively higher than maths. Predicting domain self-concept from ability in that domain tends to be more accurate when the ability in the other domain is considered. Teachers should learn to consciously deal with information from internal comparison (Dickhäuser, 2005) and verify whether or not their impression of a student's ability in a given domain is accurate. pointed out premature domain specifications may result in giving up on a perceived inferior domain without examining one's ability/achievement accurately. The myth of 'maths person' or 'verbal person' may limit someone's possibility of development in the weaker domain. Since research has shown that ASC influences students' course selection in the future (Marsh & Yeung, 1997) , guidance should be provided to students who perceive themselves less capable in one domain due to crossdomain comparisons.
